Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of Reduced Population Size on the Genomics of Adaptation during Drosophila Experimental Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reduced population size, and the inbreeding that results from it, is known to reduce the functional response to selection. The present research measures the genomic impact of inbreeding on selection in the common lab fruit fly. Most animal research uses laboratory populations that are inbred, but such inbred animals may not be good research models for species that have large population sizes like humans. Understanding the genomic effects of inbreeding will help elucidate the plight of small populations undergoing intense selection. This is of great importance for such applied settings as conservation since endangered species often have very small populations. The work will also help researchers understand how populations adapt to novel, stressful environments.

The research involves sequencing pooled DNA from nearly 30 Drosophila populations maintained at small census sizes. Half of these populations were subjected to strong selection for starvation resistance, while no selection was directly imposed on the remainder. The functional response to strong selection has already been shown to be impaired in these inbred flies. Genomic analysis will reveal the genetic machinery that has impaired their response to selection. These genomic findings will then be compared to genomic studies of fruit fly populations maintained at much larger population sizes. The comparison will reveal the genetic basis of reduced response to selection with inbreeding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Selection experiments have shown that reduced population size and the resulting inbreeding can severely limit the response to selection in animal populations. However, only small-scale studies have examined the causes of this phenomenon. This project seeks characterize the impact of reduced population size on the genomics of laboratory adaptation in Drosophila melanogaster, the fruit fly. There is a great deal of scientific significance to this project as the majority of fruit fly laboratory populations worldwide are inbred. However, such inbred organisms may not be ideal models for species in nature that have large population sizes. This project could reveal the genomics of this problem in explicit detail. Understanding the effects of population size on adaptation could also provide a great deal of insight into the plight of small populations facing extinction, especially under  evolutionary settings like epidemics, conservation efforts, and speciation.

The funded research involved sequencing DNA from 18 experimentally evolved fruit fly populations maintained at small census sizes. Half of these populations were subjected to selection for starvation resistance, while no direct selection was imposed on the remaining half. The phenotypic response to selection in these flies has already been characterized, and we know they show a diminished response to selection compared to populations maintained at larger census sizes. At this point, DNA has been extracted and sequenced from pools of individuals sampled from each of these populations. The data have been processed and the quality is very high. We also have sufficient read coverage to accurately estimate allele frequencies for each population. The data are currently being analyzed and we plan to compare our findings with comparable  genomic work on populations maintained at much larger census sizes. These findings should yield unprecedented insight into the genomic basis of the effects of inbreeding on adaptation.
